Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: Are there any events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation? If yet then list 10 such events.
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result:
Based on the provided information, there isn't enough detail to provide a specific list of 10 events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation. However, we can mention some well-known global events and organizations related to conservation efforts. Some examples include:

1. United Nations Climate Change Conferences (COP)
2. Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD)
3. World Wildlife Fund (WWF)
4. Conservation International (CI)
5. IUCN - International Union for Conservation of Nature
6. REDD+ (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation)
7. CITES (Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Fauna and Flora)
8. Global Environment Facility (GEF)
9. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)
10. Earth Day Network

Please note that this list is not exhaustive, but rather provides a starting point for exploring various events and initiatives focused on environmental conservation.

source.content: income source for these ecosystems and communities that live within them When tourism collapsed during the toughest times of COVID it was the finance generated from REDD+ credits that helped conservation projects continue keep people employed and generate other benefits  Treedom What was your latest work mainly dealing with What were the big challenges and questions that you were facing Christina Ender During the last 2 ½ years I have been working on something that is called REDD+ nesting REDD+ nesting defines approaches measures and rules to integrate individual REDD+ projects into the broader national systems REDD+ was intended to be rolled out on a national level however the development of the REDD+ policy elements required to do so is lengthy technical and expensive The completion of that has in some circumstances been delayed In the meantime voluntary carbon projects developed independently and have so far operated in parallel to and somewhat independent from a national system

sector that encourages companies from all over the world to adopt sustainable policies to respect corporate social responsibility and to make the results of the actions undertaken public To assess our impact on the selected objectives we are using the SDGs Action Manager an online platform created by integrating the B Impact Assessment of the US non-profit organisation B Lab with the ten principles of the United Nations Global Compact The close collaboration between the two international organisations has given rise to a tool capable of indicating how much a company is contributing to the achievement of a single objective compared to its potential in percentage terms These are the results of the impact analysis conducted in the  Impact Report In  Treedom became a certified B Corporation part of the global network of companies that stand out for their high environmental and social performance Treedom obtained the B Corp certification with  points out of a minimum of 80 to be certified

Large companies in the EU will be obliged to publicly share data on their impact on the environment people the planet and the sustainability risks they face We look at the new European Transparency Directive Called the CSRD which stands for Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive it replaces the current Non-Financial Reporting Directive NFRDThe CSRD was introduced to define a common standard for corporate sustainability reporting across the EU in much the same way as for financial reporting The new directive which will be implemented at national level will cover a broader range of companies than the legislation it replaces While today the NFRD covers just over 11 companies the new legislation will cover almost 50 The most interesting point is the provision of a shared standard for data presentation This will make it easier - for anyone interested from sustainability experts and information professionals to associations and private citizens - to compare the performance of companies

Research shows that a significant proportion of the population places the responsibility for achieving sustainability goals firmly on businesses Today companies are beginning to understand just how crucial it is to respond to that expectation But finding a meaningful way to contribute that fits neatly into existing business operations and manages to inspire customers clients and employees is a complicated task   It’s often the case that well-meaning sustainable initiatives fall flat  Companies try to do everything in-house without leveraging the correct partnership Some lack clear ownership or become tick box exercises that sit in a siloed part of the business or are placed at the bottom of the to-do list for busy staff Others simply fail to resonate with stakeholders - forgettable generic gestures that neither foster connection nor lead to long-lasting value for the business  So when choosing a partner with which to make a sustainable commitment companies need to ask some vital

projects in Tanzania I was able to accompany our partner for a day The meeting point was the nursery in Arusha where the seeds are grown into small seedlings In addition to fruit trees such as mango papaya or orange trees that have health-promoting properties such as the majestic neem trees are also nurtured here Luca explained that the latter are particularly popular among the older generation of smallholder farmers who appreciate their uses in health and personal care The younger generation prefer trees with fruits that they can consume or sell as they prioritise the economic benefits After having loaded the seedlings into the car we drove out of the city to meet a group of smallholder farmers in one of the communities we work with In each community we always include local authorities such as priests or mayors This creates a good system of checks and balances as community leaders keep meticulous records of recipients and number of trees received just like our partnersMany

Commerce & Products.question: What are the key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce?
Commerce & Products.result:
There are several types of key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce. These include:

1. Supplier relationships: Businesses rely on suppliers for raw materials, components, and services needed to produce goods or provide services. Strong supplier relationships ensure reliable access to quality inputs while also supporting local economies and responsible sourcing practices.
2. Retail partnerships: Brick-and-mortar retailers, e-commerce platforms, and marketplaces often form strategic partnerships to expand customer reach, share resources, and improve overall efficiency. Examples include exclusive product launches, joint marketing campaigns, and co-branded products.
3. Nonprofit partnerships: Many businesses engage with nonprofits through sponsorships, cause-related marketing, or philanthropic giving programs. These partnerships help businesses demonstrate their commitment to social and environmental causes while also benefiting the nonprofit organizations involved.
4. Community partnerships: Companies may collaborate with local governments, community organizations, and other businesses to address social, economic, or environmental issues affecting their region. This type of collaboration helps build stronger communities and supports long-term business success.
5. Cross-sectoral partnerships: Collaboration between different sectors (e.g., private, public, nonprofit) can lead to innovative solutions and increased impact. For example, public-private partnerships can facilitate infrastructure development or disaster relief efforts.

Employment & Opportunities.question: What employment or educational opportunities are currently available?
Employment & Opportunities.result:
There are several employment and educational opportunities available based on the provided information. Some options include:

1. Jobs in consultancy, environmental science, and sustainability sectors where companies seek expertise in reducing their carbon footprint and operating in a more sustainable manner.
2. Opportunities to contribute to finding solutions for a greener planet and invest professionally in a growing sector with promising growth prospects.
3. Positions in various fields such as renewable energy, sustainable agriculture, sustainable finance, and eco-friendly consumer products within the sustainability sector.
4. Green funeral service providers who specialize in offering natural and eco-friendly alternatives to traditional burials and cremations.
5. Bicycle fisherman positions in cities like Amsterdam where there is a need to remove abandoned bicycles from waterways.
6. Eco-therapy practices for individuals seeking holistic mental health support through outdoor experiences in nature.
7. Legal careers focusing on environmental law, including advocating for wildlife conservation, supporting clean energy initiatives, and addressing climate change-related issues.
8. Educational programs and courses related to sustainability, environmental studies, and related disciplines, providing students with knowledge and skills needed to pursue careers in the sector.

source.content: consultants and environmental scientists These jobs are typically in high demand because they allow companies to reduce their carbon footprint operate in a more sustainable manner and communicate their environmental commitment  Working in the sustainability sector can mean both contributing to finding solutions for a greener planet and investing professionally in a sector with promising growth prospects The sustainability sector is focused on finding ways to reduce humanity's impact on the environment and promote social and economic development in a way that is sustainable for the long term This can include a wide range of activities from renewable energy and sustainable agriculture to sustainable finance and eco-friendly consumer products As concern about the environment and social justice grows the demand for sustainable products and services is likely to increase creating opportunities for professionals in this field This is what Artificial Intelligence has answered us while you

The global economy is changing and the way companies incorporate sustainability into their plans is changing Workers are looking for jobs that aren't just work - but have meaning Real transformation requires new jobs in the sustainability sector that can drive change  But along with the more predictable roles these changes have also brought about a whole new raft of weird and wonderful activities… here are 5 green jobs that we guarantee you haven't heard of yet Really Yes they exist The trend towards more sustainability in our everyday lives doesn't stop at death  Green funerals offer a more natural and eco-friendly alternative They use caskets or covers made from natural biodegradable and sustainable materials and little or no embalming Amsterdam is famous for having thousands of bicycles in its canals but it’s a problem that is widespread – almost every major city with rivers has the same issue The metal and tin is a danger for living creatures and disturbs the ecosystem of the

in its canals but it’s a problem that is widespread – almost every major city with rivers has the same issue The metal and tin is a danger for living creatures and disturbs the ecosystem of the rivers The solution bicycle fishermen With a boat a claw and magnets they fish for bicycles which are then recycled as scrap metal The circle of life  Do you care about the environment and want to help people Then this job could be right for you Eco-therapists work with external experiences in nature The idea by connecting our inner self with the outer mental health problems can be improved We discussed the related benefits of forest bathing here For many young professionals the question of meaning is becoming more and more central when choosing a career This is also true for lawyers If you want to fight for the earth's right to survive and fight that fight in the courtroom instead of the streets you might find your calling here Environmental lawyers protect wildlife work for clean energy and

Employment & Opportunities.result:
The passage mentions several employee or participant benefits related to Treedom's services. These include:

1. Ongoing engagement: Recipients of a tree through Treedom's platform remain connected and engaged with the tree, its project, and its ongoing impact. This fosters a sense of shared achievement for everyone involved.
2. Bespoke communication support: Treedom provides customizable communication packages to help companies effectively convey their commitment to sustainability and shared forest growth.
3. Integration with company branding: Treedom supplies materials that seamlessly integrate with a company's existing brand and marketing channels, ensuring the message reaches the desired target audience.
4. Demonstrated corporate responsibility: Growing trees with Treedom allows companies to demonstrate their commitment to sustainability and environmental stewardship to clients, customers, and employees alike.

Large companies in the EU will be obliged to publicly share data on their impact on the environment people the planet and the sustainability risks they face We look at the new European Transparency Directive Called the CSRD which stands for Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive it replaces the current Non-Financial Reporting Directive NFRDThe CSRD was introduced to define a common standard for corporate sustainability reporting across the EU in much the same way as for financial reporting The new directive which will be implemented at national level will cover a broader range of companies than the legislation it replaces While today the NFRD covers just over 11 companies the new legislation will cover almost 50 The most interesting point is the provision of a shared standard for data presentation This will make it easier - for anyone interested from sustainability experts and information professionals to associations and private citizens - to compare the performance of companies

was clear We are not working alone Jaron Pazi Treedom Country Manager D-A-C-H talks about how and why we grow trees around the world Collaboration and community are extremely important to us at Treedom and our Greentech squad  was made up of representatives from different teams within the business Representing our small Treedom community here are Vanina Giulia T Jaron and Anja who take care of collaborations with companies while Camilla and Giulia S work with the media From left Treedom representatives at the Greentech Festival Camilla Melosi Giulia Stirpe Jaron Pazi Agnieszka Biernacka Vanina Ricci e Giulia Tolotti 'We are thrilled to have participated in the Greentech Festival Our goal was to show how Treedom combines tree planting projects with an engaging digital experience We met companies journalists sportsmen artists and students all happy to tell their story and curious to discover ours - Jaron Pazi Country Manager D-A-C-H 'I was struck by the determination of the people I met

income source for these ecosystems and communities that live within them When tourism collapsed during the toughest times of COVID it was the finance generated from REDD+ credits that helped conservation projects continue keep people employed and generate other benefits  Treedom What was your latest work mainly dealing with What were the big challenges and questions that you were facing Christina Ender During the last 2 ½ years I have been working on something that is called REDD+ nesting REDD+ nesting defines approaches measures and rules to integrate individual REDD+ projects into the broader national systems REDD+ was intended to be rolled out on a national level however the development of the REDD+ policy elements required to do so is lengthy technical and expensive The completion of that has in some circumstances been delayed In the meantime voluntary carbon projects developed independently and have so far operated in parallel to and somewhat independent from a national system

Research & Innovation.question: What are the latest publications, research findings, or introduced technologies?
Research & Innovation.result: I am not aware of any specific recent publications, research findings, or introduced technologies related to bringing about a greener future. However, there have been several ongoing efforts and initiatives across various industries and sectors aimed at reducing carbon emissions, promoting renewable energy sources, and addressing climate change more broadly. Some examples include the Paris Agreement, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) reports, and numerous international conferences and summits focused on environmental sustainability and greenhouse gas mitigation strategies. Additionally, many countries, companies, and individuals continue to invest in clean technology innovations such as electric vehicles, solar panels, wind turbines, and other environmentally-friendly solutions.

Research & Innovation.question: What research grants or innovation awards have been recently distributed?
Research & Innovation.result: I am not aware of any specific research grants or innovation awards that were recently distributed related to bringing us towards a greener future. However, there are several organizations and programs that provide funding for projects focused on sustainability, renewable energy, and environmental conservation. Some examples include the European Commission's Horizon 2020 program, the United States Department of Energy's Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy (ARPA-E), and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation's Global Grand Challenges Exploration initiative. These programs often announce new grant opportunities throughout the year, so it's worth checking their websites for recent developments.

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What organizations, institutions, or entities is the organization collaborating with?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Based on the provided information, Treedom is collaborating with several notable organizations, institutions, and entities. Some of these include:

1. B Lab (United States): A non-profit organization that provides resources and tools for businesses to become more socially and environmentally responsible. They developed the SDGs Action Manager, which Treedom uses to measure its impact on selected objectives related to the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
2. B Corp Certification: Treedom has achieved B Corp certification, demonstrating its commitment to high environmental and social performance. This certification is awarded by the international B Corp community, which includes other like-minded companies around the world.
3. United Nations Global Compact: Treedom works closely with the United Nations Global Compact, an initiative that encourages businesses to align their operations and strategies with ten universal principles in the areas of human rights, labor, environment, and anti-corruption.
4. Various Countries: Treedom carries out projects in multiple countries, aiming to deliver environmental and social benefits globally. Some specific examples mentioned include Italy, where the Florence commercial register lists the company, and Spain, where the tax code/VAT and corporate stock information are registered.
5. Other Companies and Organizations: Treedom also partners with numerous companies and organizations that share their vision for sustainability and positive environmental and social impact. While no specific names were mentioned, it is clear that Treedom actively engages with diverse stakeholders to achieve its goals.

source.content: accountable for their actions  Several B Corps including Ecoalf have engaged with their audiences to highlight the power of individual actions In this year’s anti-Black Friday campaign Ecoalf encourages people to “Break the habit not the planet” and explore various alternatives to lower your own impact Can you tell us a bit more about the B Corp concept and how choosing to spend money with B Corps can make a differenceThe B Corp certification looks at how the way a company operates can create benefits for all people communities and the planet It doesn’t mean a company is perfect but it is committed to measuring and continuously improving its impact  By buying from working for and partnering with B Corps you're helping support companies that are committed to using business as a force for good from reducing their own environmental footprint addressing inequalities in supply chain empowering marginalized communities diversifying the workplace and promoting interdependence 4 And finally

sector that encourages companies from all over the world to adopt sustainable policies to respect corporate social responsibility and to make the results of the actions undertaken public To assess our impact on the selected objectives we are using the SDGs Action Manager an online platform created by integrating the B Impact Assessment of the US non-profit organisation B Lab with the ten principles of the United Nations Global Compact The close collaboration between the two international organisations has given rise to a tool capable of indicating how much a company is contributing to the achievement of a single objective compared to its potential in percentage terms These are the results of the impact analysis conducted in the  Impact Report In  Treedom became a certified B Corporation part of the global network of companies that stand out for their high environmental and social performance Treedom obtained the B Corp certification with  points out of a minimum of 80 to be certified

Philips dutch company leader in health technology decided to create two Forests with Treedom planting  trees in Ecuador Kenya Madagascar and Tanzania The initiative first involved the employees of the Mother  Child Care department before being integrated into the Philips Sustainability Ambassador Program We talked with Mirko Cartei Senior Director Innovation Lead Mother  Child Care to learn more about the operation Mirko Philips decided to give a tree to all its employees in the Mother and Child Care department globally How did the idea come about The idea came up by connecting the dots on how to reward our new employees' onboarding next to recognize the existing ones in their development path in our MotherChild Care team spread across the globe When I discovered on social media what Treedom is doing it was an instant “click” We recognize that greening the planet one tree at a time resonates with our mission too to groom and develop our teammates How did you introduce the project and

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What are the mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result: The mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations involve achieving common goals related to environmental protection, climate change mitigation, and sustainability. These collaborations aim to create awareness about the importance of reforestation, promote eco-friendly practices, and encourage individuals and organizations to contribute towards a greener planet. Additionally, these collaborations may also focus on sharing knowledge, resources, and expertise to enhance the effectiveness of respective efforts. Overall, the desired outcome of these collaborations is to collectively work towards a more sustainable future while fostering connections and inspiring shared achievements.

gestures that neither foster connection nor lead to long-lasting value for the business  So when choosing a partner with which to make a sustainable commitment companies need to ask some vital questions is this project able to bring about real impact Will it stand up to scrutiny And when satisfied on those counts - how effectively can this initiative communicate the company’s values Is it an interesting conversation-starter Will the investment lead to a strong sense of shared achievement Treedom’s proposition gives a resounding yes to each of those questions Through a unique digital tree-planting platform companies can invest in a branded ‘forest’ of trees which are planted by project partners in sustainable agroforestry systems across Africa Latin America and Asia and monitor their impact online from anywhere in the world The impacts are long-lasting and wide-ranging “It’s a way to achieve two things at once - the social benefit that’s a little more rare alongside the environmental
